awd_titl_txt: Exploring the High Energy Frontier with the CMS Electromagnetic Calorimeter
awd_abstract_narration:
The Standard Model of particle physics has been a remarkably successful theory, agreeing with several decades of experimental observations involving weak, electromagnetic, and strong interactions. The LHC discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 was further confirmation of this success.  However, the Standard Model remains an incomplete theory. This research will address some of the most intriguing and pressing questions in particle physics--what is the nature of electroweak symmetry breaking? What is dark matter? Are there extra spatial dimensions? In particular, the Higgs boson will be used to constrain the Standard Model and to probe for new physics. The research carried out through this award will exploit the excellent performance of the electromagnetic calorimeter of the CMS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider facility at CERN in Switzerland to pursue strategically selected physics channels with common final states and analysis methods. 

This project combines important contributions to the CMS electromagnetic calorimeter with compelling physics studies in electron and photon final states, in addition to contributions to the operation, maintenance, and calibration of the CMS calorimeter, and involvement in the Phase-2 upgrade of the electromagnetic calorimeter electronics to fully exploit the opportunities at the High-Luminosity LHC. Through direct studies of the Higgs boson in the H->WW, H->gamma gamma, H->Zgamma channels, the question of electroweak symmetry breaking will be elucidated. Additionally, these channels will help constrain  new physics through indirect means. The group is also searching directly for new particles (via HH->bbgammagamma, h->aa->4photons) that may exist due to supersymmetry or extra dimensions. In addition, the study of di-Higgs production will probe the stability of the vacuum. This work also includes mentoring of women in physics at Northeastern University and engagement with undergraduates in research through the Northeastern cooperative education program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main goals of the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC) are to elucidate the origins of electroweak symmetry breaking and to search for new physics beyond the standard model (SM) at the high energy frontier. The CMS detector was designed with an emphasis on precision photon and lepton measurements, which were crucial for the discovery of the Higgs boson and will continue to be critical for future discoveries. This award funded the work of PI Toyoko Orimoto and her research group at Northeastern University. PI Orimoto is an expert on electromagnetic calorimetry in CMS and has led a wide range of physics analysis with electromagnetic objects. Additionally, she has applied her expertise in detector technologies to a new, precision timing detector for CMS, in preparation for the High-Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC).

PI Orimoto's goals leverage her group's expertise in physics studies with electromagnetic final states, while addressing some of the most important issues presented at the LHC. In particular, the group has a major focus on beyond-standard-model (BSM) studies utilizing the recently discovered Higgs boson as a probe for new physics. In pursuit of these goals, the Orimoto group pursued several analyses, with an emphasis on analyses with photon final states that were thus far unexplored by CMS. These include explorations of double Higgs production, which is an important test of the SM, while also constraining BSM scenarios such as models of extra-dimensions. The Orimoto group has pursued the double Higgs decay channel with two b-quarks and two photons, which is one of the most sensitive channels, as well as the channel with two W-bosons and two photons, which will be the first search in this final state for double Higgs production. In addition, the Orimoto group produced the first CMS search for exotic Higgs decays to two light supersymmetric pseudoscalars, which subsequently each decay to two photons, resulting in a final state with four photons.

Precision electromagnetic calorimetry is crucial for measuring the properties of the Higgs boson and pursuing BSM physics searches in electromagnetic final states. The Orimoto group has been dedicated to the successful operation of the CMS electromagnetic calorimeter (ECAL) and the Phase-2 upgrade of the ECAL for the High-Luminosity LHC. The Orimoto group has contributed to many areas within the CMS ECAL group, including the L1 hardware-level trigger, clustering, calibration and alignment, and test beam studies for the upgrade. 

Moreover, the Orimoto group has applied its expertise in precision timing from the ECAL to the new MIP Timing Detector (MTD), another crucial aspect of the Phase-2 upgrade of CMS. The MTD project is a new detector layer for the CMS Phase-II upgrade that is dedicated to providing precision time measurements of minimum ionizing particles. Precision timing will be an important way to mitigate the impact of high pileup at the High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC), while also introducing new capabilities to the detector. The Orimoto group has made significant contributions to system testing and lab measurements of sensors for both the barrel and endcap timing layers of the MTD. 

In terms of broader impacts, PI Orimoto has been dedicated to promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion at all levels in the CMS Collaboration, as well as at her university, college, department, and the wider academic community. PI Orimoto served as a member (2018-2020) and also as co-chair (2020-present) of the CMS Diversity Office, whose goal is to foster a working environment where all members of the CMS Collaboration can thrive and bring in their talents. In addition, PI Orimoto served as a planning committee member (2018-2020) and co-chair (2021) of the Women of Color in the Academy Conference, hosted by Northeastern University. Moreover, PI Orimoto serves as the chair of the Northeastern Physics Department Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion committee, and as the physics department representative to the Northeastern College of Science Equity, Diversity, Inclusion, and Justice Committee. PI Orimoto has pursued numerous initiatives (such as mentoring graduate and undergraduate women in physics and developing research awards for undergraduate women in physics) and has contributed to many outreach activities (such as serving as keynote speaker at a Girl Scout STEM and community college conferences).
